Line 218: Line 218:
Since the 1990 U.S. elections, Donald Trump has made contributions to campaigns of both Republican Party candidates (including [[John McCain]], [[Rudolph Giuliani]], [[Newt Gingrich]], and [[George W. Bush]])<ref name=trumpsdonations>{{cite web|url=http://www.opensecrets.org/news/2011/02/donald-trumps-donations-to-democrats.html|publisher=OpenSecrets.org|title = Donald Trump's Donations to Democrats, Club for Growth's Busy Day and More in Capital Eye Opener|first=Zachary|last=Newkirk|date=February 17, 2011}}</ref> as well as Democratic Party candidates (including [[Ted Kennedy]], [[John Kerry]], [[Tom Daschle]], [[Joe Biden]], [[Harry Reid]], [[Rahm Emanuel]], [[Hillary Clinton]], [[Anthony Weiner]], [[Charles Schumer]], [[Kirsten Gillibrand]], and [[Charles Rangel]]).<ref name=trumpsdonations/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0111/47924.html |title=Hollywood helps Rahm haul in $10.6M - Meredith Shiner |publisher=Politico.Com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-02-21/trump-s-run-for-president-requires-memory-loss-kevin-hassett.html|title=Trump's Run for President Requires Memory Loss: Kevin Hassett|first=Kevin|last=Hasssett|authorlink=Kevin Hassett|publisher=[[Business Week]]|date=February 21, 2011}}</ref>
Since the 1990 U.S. elections, Donald Trump has made contributions to campaigns of both Republican Party candidates (including [[John McCain]], [[Rudolph Giuliani]], [[Newt Gingrich]], and [[George W. Bush]])<ref name=trumpsdonations>{{cite web|url=http://www.opensecrets.org/news/2011/02/donald-trumps-donations-to-democrats.html|publisher=OpenSecrets.org|title = Donald Trump's Donations to Democrats, Club for Growth's Busy Day and More in Capital Eye Opener|first=Zachary|last=Newkirk|date=February 17, 2011}}</ref> as well as Democratic Party candidates (including [[Ted Kennedy]], [[John Kerry]], [[Tom Daschle]], [[Joe Biden]], [[Harry Reid]], [[Rahm Emanuel]], [[Hillary Clinton]], [[Anthony Weiner]], [[Charles Schumer]], [[Kirsten Gillibrand]], and [[Charles Rangel]]).<ref name=trumpsdonations/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0111/47924.html |title=Hollywood helps Rahm haul in $10.6M - Meredith Shiner |publisher=Politico.Com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-02-21/trump-s-run-for-president-requires-memory-loss-kevin-hassett.html|title=Trump's Run for President Requires Memory Loss: Kevin Hassett|first=Kevin|last=Hasssett|authorlink=Kevin Hassett|publisher=[[Business Week]]|date=February 21, 2011}}</ref>
â
===2012 presidential candidacy===
+
==2012 presidential candidacy, political statements, and backlash==
Trump has said that he is seriously considering running for [[President of the United States]] in [[United States presidential election, 2012|the 2012 election]].<ref>Madison, Lucy (October 4, 2010) [http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20018405-503544.html "Donald Trump for President in 2012?"], CBS News. Retrieved October 4, 2010.</ref><ref>Zwick, Jesse (October 4, 2010) [http://washingtonindependent.com/99472/donald-trump-for-president "Donald Trump for President?"], The Washington Independent. Retrieved October 4, 2010.</ref> In his [[Republican Party (United States) presidential primaries, 2012|primary campaign]], Trump has made a February speech to a [[Conservative Political Action Conference|CPAC]] gathering,<ref name="thall11">{{cite web|url=http://townhall.com/tipsheet/katiepavlich/2011/02/10/crowd_goes_wild_over_donald_trump_speech_at_cpac|title=Crowd Goes Wild Over Donald Trump Speech at CPAC|publisher=[[Townhall.com]]|date=February 10, 2011|accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> an early venue for candidates considering a presidential run, as a write-in candidate in its [[straw poll]] for the office. A Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll released in March 2011 found Donald Trump leading among potential contenders for the Republican nomination for President of the United States, one point ahead of former Massachusetts Governor [[Mitt Romney]].<ref>Haberman, Maggie (March 7, 2011).[http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/politics/Trump_tops_Romney__Pawlenty-117496043.html Trump tops Romney, Pawlenty]. ''NBC New York''. Retrieved March 7, 2011.</ref> A Newsweek poll conducted February 2011 showed Trump within a few points of Obama, with many voters undecided in the November 2012 general election for President of the United States against [[Barack Obama]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2011-02-21/obama-hits-50-percent-approval-rating-according-to-new-newsweekdaily-beast-poll/?cid=hp:beastoriginalsL2|title=Obama Hits 50 Percent Approval Rating, According to New Newsweek/Daily Beast Poll|publisher=The Newsweek / Daily Beast Company LLC|first=Douglas|last=Schoen|date=February 21, 2011|accessdate=April 14, 2011}}</ref> A poll released in April 2011 by Public Policy Polling showed Trump having a nine point lead in a potential contest for the Republican nomination for President of the United States.<ref>Shadid, Aliyah (April 15, 2011).[http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/2011/04/15/2011-04-15_donald_trump_takes_lead_in_gop_primary_poll_beats_romney_huckabee_palin_gingrich.html?r=news/politics Donald Trump takes lead in GOP primary poll, beats Romney, Huckabee, Palin, Gingrich, Bachmann, Paul].''New York Daily News''. Retrieved April 17, 2011.</ref>
Trump has said that he is seriously considering running for [[President of the United States]] in [[United States presidential election, 2012|the 2012 election]].<ref>Madison, Lucy (October 4, 2010) [http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20018405-503544.html "Donald Trump for President in 2012?"], CBS News. Retrieved October 4, 2010.</ref><ref>Zwick, Jesse (October 4, 2010) [http://washingtonindependent.com/99472/donald-trump-for-president "Donald Trump for President?"], The Washington Independent. Retrieved October 4, 2010.</ref> In his [[Republican Party (United States) presidential primaries, 2012|primary campaign]], Trump has made a February speech to a [[Conservative Political Action Conference|CPAC]] gathering,<ref name="thall11">{{cite web|url=http://townhall.com/tipsheet/katiepavlich/2011/02/10/crowd_goes_wild_over_donald_trump_speech_at_cpac|title=Crowd Goes Wild Over Donald Trump Speech at CPAC|publisher=[[Townhall.com]]|date=February 10, 2011|accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> an early venue for candidates considering a presidential run, as a write-in candidate in its [[straw poll]] for the office. A Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll released in March 2011 found Donald Trump leading among potential contenders for the Republican nomination for President of the United States, one point ahead of former Massachusetts Governor [[Mitt Romney]].<ref>Haberman, Maggie (March 7, 2011).[http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/politics/Trump_tops_Romney__Pawlenty-117496043.html Trump tops Romney, Pawlenty]. ''NBC New York''. Retrieved March 7, 2011.</ref> A Newsweek poll conducted February 2011 showed Trump within a few points of Obama, with many voters undecided in the November 2012 general election for President of the United States against [[Barack Obama]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2011-02-21/obama-hits-50-percent-approval-rating-according-to-new-newsweekdaily-beast-poll/?cid=hp:beastoriginalsL2|title=Obama Hits 50 Percent Approval Rating, According to New Newsweek/Daily Beast Poll|publisher=The Newsweek / Daily Beast Company LLC|first=Douglas|last=Schoen|date=February 21, 2011|accessdate=April 14, 2011}}</ref> A poll released in April 2011 by Public Policy Polling showed Trump having a nine point lead in a potential contest for the Republican nomination for President of the United States.<ref>Shadid, Aliyah (April 15, 2011).[http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/2011/04/15/2011-04-15_donald_trump_takes_lead_in_gop_primary_poll_beats_romney_huckabee_palin_gingrich.html?r=news/politics Donald Trump takes lead in GOP primary poll, beats Romney, Huckabee, Palin, Gingrich, Bachmann, Paul].''New York Daily News''. Retrieved April 17, 2011.</ref>
